title: Deployment on the Market
segmentation: First of all, I would like to thank the organizers because they have given me a very good title tattoo.
I would like to discuss with you.

For today, I'm not sure everybody will be happy with my conclusions about this particular topic, and if I got right, the message of what has to be discussed at this point, I think it is the right moment since we have word that common framework is already underway.
And well developed from the technical point of view, is the right moment to think about possible deployment on the market.
What does that mean?
From my point of view, I have always been between.
Market real concrete activities with the customer and research from my point of view deployement on the market means making money out of becoming framework.
So is it possible?
Is it likely?
Do we want it?
Let's see and also I like this exercise because it gave me the opportunity to do some historical research.
I went back to the time I was a very young product manager, found some very nice slides from before the Internet bubble.
You know about that.
It was maybe it is not like the subprime bubble, but may have something to do with it.
Something we have probably forgotten, but it is.

Related to what we're discussing today, so we look some lessons that we can learn from the past and we look at the two problems we have that are typical of any new product you want to introduce that problem of the Accessibility and the problem of value.
And then I said I was probably too enthusiastic.
Possible wait out.
Actually, I don't know if there is a way out.
We have to discuss it together.
I have questions mostly.
So historical research number one.
This is from 2002.
From our gurus garner.
At the time the company ICT companies took people like me are met us with Ghana group slides and sent us to onto the market too.
Preach the gospel that rules at the time.
Supply chain integration.
Does it sound familiar to you?
It was at that time.
I mean more than 10,000 years ago.
They predicted that 60% of SCM would be done outside the enterprise and that quite easy.
I mean, that's not a terrific prediction, but the second statement is like I've thrown the stone and I hide my heart because they say yes.
But if you do that, you will probably result in most cases in lower profitability.
So how can you expect the company to actually do that?
And indeed they didn't do that, so, but looking from the poor man perspective this was known and preached by Guru's voting by important ICT companies.
For sure we will have success stories we want to sell is the common framework.
We have success story to learn from and to implement.
I mean business models value proposition that we can replicate for the common frame.
So the question, sorry.
Is.
How to make money with interoperability.
Do not hide ourselves.
We need to make money anyway, even if we are in the first level that it means we publish the standard and for sure that we use it.
That level of institutions of let's say standardization groups of committees and so on.
They need money anyway to survive to organize conferences like these too.
I mean, it is needed to have some sustainable.
Business model to do that?
And that's one model that tries to address the widest population of customers.
I mean, all all the company's to jump into the standard into the common framework.
In this case, the second approach that was quite popular before the Internet bubble was build a platform and they will come here it is.
It is a marketplace.
It is the data interchange.
For I don't know manufacturing sector.
It is here we have wonderful programmers.
So you just see.
Simply, the companies will buy in because they need it to link their business processes and so on.
Well, you know the story.
Those attempts have completely disappeared in a matter of months.
Alot of money spent on marketing fund.
I mean venture capital is getting very angry with younger engineers and so we know the story.
Then there is another approach which is a bit more practical and as a lesser population numbers which is bundling interoperability with logistic services.
That being common companies like Vector Axiom, SCM.
I don't know if they are still active, probably not.
I know UPS, we're doing a lot of marketing of their ECM services, and there's probably something has survived, but for sure they have not achieved mass adoption.
Tender is a an approach that access has succeeded, but not on a large scale that is building a platform.
Go to the supply chain leader.
I go to Proctor, I go to large logistic operators and sell it to them.
You use this platform to integrate your business partners and so the supply chain is integrated.
There's been a lot of work, and many of those companies, starting from crossword crosswords, disappeared in six months.
It was acquired by IBM that probably they produce the web sphere based on that new wow, but all these attempts Biztalk, I don't know if it is still alive from Max.
Probably not.
Those attempts have been actually transformed.
They are really well the business to business was good for marketing at the beginning, but what they do actually is enterprise application integration.
They used within the organization as development tools basically, so we cannot say that.

That kind of approach really fulfills the interoperability requirements that we have, so the question can be translated as anyone ever made real money, I mean sustainable income for their companies out of interoperability in the supply chains, right?
Not interpret in general, but in the supply chain, can we find such a success story?
Or probably we are going to be the first, hopefully.
We see that this was already introduced by by Frank.
I don't want to go into the details very complicated.
There are some success story of standardization in specific sectors, like for example in the Indian Railways list.
Top TSI is working because where the actors are few they are mostly let's say oriented.
Sorry they are oriented by the regulation.
They are easy to let's say make them sit at the same table.
And they are working on their own objective that, for example, in this case is making their railway system more efficient.
In that case, you can have a success.
They agree on the standard implemented platform and and it is working same for example in the in the.
Aeronautic sector with this if rate from from ayata and that's works and so we had these islands of interoperability.
But they have different purposes.
What really we're trying to achieve is to.
First, speak to those guys in the center that are actually those who are integrating the supply chain.
I mean the three PS the freight forwarders.
Those are really the links between the various nodes of the supply chain to speak to them and to bridge.
The different islands of interoperability to achieve some benefits that are evident, and Wolfgang mentioned this benefits there are they are there.
You will have more speed, more flexibility for the customer.
It would be equally efficient.
That's all the rage now.
Less energy consumption.
And finally the commonality aligre perfect.
This is benefits and they are evident we don't have to repeat them.
The problem is that between benefits.
Value for the user.
There is quite a huge gap and that's what we have to bridge.
But let's focus first on the first problem.
So there are benefits we all agreed on.
Don't discuss that more, but why is it so difficult to sell?
Because it's terribly difficult to set for those with track that.
First, maybe scant Accessibility.
I don't think we are at the level of Accessibility that can bring in into the common frame into the interval ability preference.
The majority of users, including as a myth.
This is another historical lighter found bit more recent 2006 from AMR that relates Accessibility intended as all the qualities of a service or product that make it easy to access for the user.
And the number of users you see that of course Google is the maximum accessible to land as the highest number of.
Users and you see where SCM is.
Do you see it down there?
So if you want to convince 510 users in a very large Corporation, maybe that is your target market perfect, but if you try to grow the population probably will have difficulties.
So let's focus for on Accessibility, because if you don't have access ability, you have no return on investment.
At least you don't have an easy to demonstrate return on investment.
So good, we have the solution you want to deploy the framework.
Make it accessible.
What does it mean?
As Frank said, do not try to include all the standards.
Try to bridge the gaps between the standards first thing, then lower the barriers.
I don't know.
As I said, I have more questions than answers.
I don't know how, but we should try to address as a Miss Ann's amiss.
They do not join standardization committees and I tend to understand why and this approach that I called interoperability as a project that works perfectly.
If you are IBM going to the Procter and sitting there with.
At 20, engineers facing other 20 engineers, this interoperability as a project works perfectly with the supply chain leaders.
Unfortunately, supply chain leaders do not control.
All the flow of goods that you want to address.
So lower the bar.
Yes, OK, so when the framework is cheap, lean and accessible, everybody knows it.
Easy to join, so will they come with a bite?
Nope.
Probably not.
There is a second motivation that is value can be as cheap as you want, but if it does no recognized value for the user difficult, they come.
But it has value.
It has benefits.
They are so evident.
Yes, they are supply chain wide benefits.
The full supply chain is better synchronized is cheaper.
I mean it does consume less energy Screener, whatever, but that's evident.
Maybe to the supply chain leader.
But it's not evident to all the partners they have to assemble, and even they have problems in convincing the parties to invest.
So there is a huge problem of value I think.
So what does it mean that?
Doc do not try to sell interoperability person in as itself, ever as a value by itself.
We know it is.
I mean this valuable but cannot be easily demonstrated to the user.
So probably the framework should be a means.
To achieve an end should be amazed to provide valuable services, something that is not possible so far.
Something that requires in the purple interoperability, and this is an example I take from a road map that we are developing in the logistics for life coordination action.

This is still to be validated, but there is an idea from some logistics service provider that future there could be an offer on the market of door to door green services becausw want to demonstrate the greenness of their supply chain and probably they will buy.

A service not just for its logistic performances, but also for the environmental performances, and that would change a bit the picture, I mean not making the service more, equal, efficient, but selling it as the coefficient.
So you have to integrate a number of actors from large to small and with the green arrows you see that each actor has to find a value out of what we propose an as to provide something.
'cause they have to buy in.
For example, DSM is they will have access as service provider, so they will have some marketing value there.
But they will have to adhere to comply to the network standards so they will have to implement the common framework.
So in conclusion, this is just an example, this service is possible only if each actor, I mean all of them find a value in it.
Some some good tradeoff between value, cost and.
That is a common framework actually that allows them to be part of this cooperative ecosystem that's absolutely necessary.
I'm not saying that it is not necessary, just saying that we are probably selling it from the bottom side.
We should start from the top.
So in conclusion, and trying to sell the common framework as as a value in itself might prove or plus very difficult.
And even this approach appears.
I propose a platform to the supply chain leaders because there is a market there.
It is valuable.
Some huge ICT companies have demonstrated that, but it is far from common.
I don't think it is common.
Absolutely not.
So we should focus more on services.
And Accessibility.
And then on services whereby we are discussing now how to do that?

And probably it could be at various level and but one outcome of this is that probably the ecosystem of the ICT for logistics will be profoundly changed 'cause it will be much more destructured in in a way that individual service components could be combined.
And the projects I did not forget that because I got a last minute input to show our projects are positioned.
In this attempt to join in a framework and to be honest, I think all our approach is that 3 ones that we are showing here.
I've done a very good job.
They have they proposed the whole package because they have to implement pilots have to propose a full solution.
So all three of them have intelligent devices.
What's three of them added as a plat F platforms?
Because they have to implement the services on top of that.
And they propose value added services.
So the question from the Commission and even of course from all of us is.
Is it valuable?
I mean, can it stay as such?
No, how can we integrate that?
For sure, in my opinion not like this.
So this is called the mortadella solution.
Sorry this is Italian and probably some of you know what it is.
It comes from a user when we try to sell it something like this.
It's OK, you are selling me the mortadella system.
That being said, big.
Round thing where all the platforms are inside they are, let's say eaten up by this thing there is one big platform for all.
This really are realistic from a market perspective.
So what can we do?
What we have just said?
Start from the standards and but for the rest, as I said, I have no no answers but questions.
Update could think off so far is 2 for sure.
Need industry support?
You need interstellar standardization for the especially for the lower layers where the technologies are bad with you cannot expect the devices to be based on.
I mean different frequencies, different communication protocols and so on.
So there you need a profound work of harmonization of standards then you don't need I think.
Well you have to live.
With the fact that there will be separate platforms distinct platform, for example, you cannot eradicate the wipe away.
They detect ESI for the railways that sits there.
It works, but you will need means to federate in some way.
This pattern probably the common framework, is a good answer to that.
And then that's the area that.
I think we have not dedicated enough attention.

We need specialized service of value that can prove to the poor man's in the companies that they at this time, by the way, have much different, more urgent problems that there is value there that actually this effort is worth something for that.
And this is all for me.
Thanks.
